image.altText: A front-on view of a large aircraft at Wilkins Aerodrome in Antarctica.

props.synopsis: Plans to build a paved runway near Davis Station in Antarctica were announced in 2017. The project was scrapped in 2021 — but not before $19 million was spent on consultants.

title.children: Consultants clean up as $19m spent on advice before runway project abandoned

image.altText: A burnt out car inside a collapsed shed.

props.synopsis: After a spate of seven emergency bushfires over two days, hot and windy conditions keep fire crews in Western Australia on high alert.

title.children: We're 'not out of the woods': Firefighters on alert in WA with more hot, windy weather on the way

image.altText: A child smiles in her new lounge room

props.synopsis: Emma and Dallas had feared that they and their nine children would be spending Christmas Day in the bush, but this week they received the best news they could have hoped for — a house they can call home for the next 18 months.

title.children: Homeless Bendigo family grateful for Christmas present: moving from a tent to a house

image.altText: Red handfish in a dark marine environment.

props.synopsis: With around only 100 of these small, peculiar fish thought to exist in the wild, the decision has been made to take a quarter of those into captivity to safeguard the population — before a worsening marine heatwave wreaks havoc.

title.children: Rescue operation to save red handfish as marine heatwave strikes off south-east Australian coast

image.altText: A Christmas tree is seen on a windy and rainy Bondi Beach in Sydney

props.synopsis: Violent thunderstorms are likely across eastern Australia this Christmas, rivalling some of the most intense and widespread storm outbreaks of the past few decades.

title.children: Severe storms to light up eastern Australia's Christmas

image.altText: a young woman in a white top speaks into a microphone

props.synopsis: In the mid 2000s, Tina Chou was a bubbly pop star on her way to the top. Almost two decades on, she has joined the growing chorus of women speaking up as the Me Too movement sweeps across Taiwan.

title.children: It took years for Tina Chou to go public with allegations against her former boss. When she did, he took her to court

image.altText: a female tennis player stands on a deck with a tennis racquet in her hand

props.synopsis: With a population of just 31, the village of Whitemore is a small point on a map, but its tennis club has triple the number of members.

title.children: This tennis club for farmers has more members than the village has residents

image.altText: Medics prepare premature babies for transport to Egypt after they were evacuated from hosptal in Gaza City.

props.synopsis: The UN is investigating whether the "rules of war" have been broken by Israel and Hamas. But what qualifies as a war crime?

title.children: The humanitarian crisis in Gaza reveals the limitations of international law

image.altText: Bruce Lehrmann outside court.

props.synopsis: Enormous volumes of evidence were given in Bruce Lehrmann's defamation trial against Network Ten and Lisa Wilkinson, and will now be considered by Federal Court Justice Michael Lee, but a decision isn't expected until well into next year.

title.children: Bruce Lehrmann's defamation trial has now wrapped, but a decision isn't expected until well into next year

image.altText: two women holding the presents

props.synopsis: Riah Holland has still been coming to terms with the heartbreaking loss of her precious family photos and heirlooms.

title.children: After a week of devastation, residents in Far North Queensland have a reason to smile

image.altText: A yellow tarp full of opened abalone, small crabs, flippers and fishing gear

props.synopsis: Eight alleged poachers have been caught in possession of more than 150 abalone and crabs in South Australia's Yorke Peninsula, police have said.

title.children: Commercial quantity of abalone seized from alleged poachers on South Australian beach

image.altText: a marijuana flag in front of white hosue

props.synopsis: The categorical pardon builds on a similar round issued just before the 2022 midterm election that pardoned thousands convicted of simple possession.

title.children: US President Joe Biden pardons thousands convicted of marijuana charges

image.altText: NomanAli

props.synopsis: Pakistan loses Noman Ali for the rest of the Test series against Australia after he was rushed to hospital for appendicitis surgery.

title.children: Spinner rushed to hospital for surgery ahead of Boxing Day Test in another blow for Pakistan's bowling stocks

image.altText: Charles Devanneaux

props.synopsis: Charles Devanneaux playfully suggested to his good friend Pierre Follenfant after a few tequilas that they should do the Sydney to Hobart — by the next morning, the journey was already planned.

title.children: How an agreement after a night on tequila led this all-French crew to the Sydney to Hobart

image.altText: Aerial of flooding in Cairns

props.synopsis: Some flood victims are living in limbo, facing weeks and months of displacement. The Cairns rental crisis means there are no homes available to accommodate those in unlivable housing, while local leaders urge Airbnb hosts to step up.

title.children: Homeless and displaced for Christmas, the Cairns rental crisis means flood victims consider leaving town

image.altText: A man climbing up a post to pull out a stop sign

props.synopsis: A man with bolt cutters removes a stop sign emblazoned with the images of three military drones.

title.children: Banksy artwork taken from London street less than an hour after it was revealed

image.altText: A man wearing glasses sits at a desk with letters in front of him. There is a Christmas tree in the background.

props.synopsis: Father Christmas is writing back to dozens of children in a Queensland country town and surrounds thanks to a local paramedic, parents and the post office.

title.children: Handwritten letters from ambo Santa keep Christmas spirit alive in Queensland country town

image.altText: Anthony Albanese looks annoyed as he addresses the media

props.synopsis: Anthony Albanese is finishing the year with a sullen electorate that can't really see past the economic pain it is feeling, and national security back in the realm of talk about border security and terrorists, writes Laura Tingle.

title.children: A sullen electorate, an opponent with lethal populism and unanswered questions: Can the PM regain control in 2024?

image.altText: A closeup of donald trump

props.synopsis: The ruling is a win for Mr Trump and his lawyers, who have sought to delay criminal cases against him as he seeks to reclaim the White House in 2024.

title.children: US Supreme Court rejects prosecutor's request in Trump election fraud case

image.altText: Two people drag calves by their limbs along an abattoir floor.

props.synopsis: The federal government has partially suspended Tasmanian Quality Meats' export registration and placed several conditions on the business. Any decisions about domestic market supply is up to the Tasmanian government.

title.children: A Tasmanian abattoir's licence to export calves has been suspended following animal welfare concerns

image.altText: A middle-aged woman smiles at the camera.

props.synopsis: Helen Bird died in 2010. Her death is being re-examined at a coronial inquest, which has heard her husband, who has been named a person of interest, has given differing accounts of Helen's state before her death.

title.children: Husband ran to landline rather than use his mobile and perform CPR when he found wife's body, inquest hears

image.altText: A still images from a cartoon-style animation showing a cord and container sending bubbles into the water near two skates.

props.synopsis: With depleted oxygen levels in Tasmania's Macquarie Harbour pushing the Maugean skate towards extinction, the salmon farming industry and federal government are combining to fund a "nano bubbles" trial.

title.children: Macquarie Harbour oxygenation trial hoped to save endangered skate

image.altText: A chinese aircraft

props.synopsis: The news sparked controversy in the island, with think tank Taiwan Economic Democracy Union warning authorities to investigate suspicions of election bribery and political interference.

title.children: Battle in the sky: China's efforts to get Taiwanese back to the island to vote

image.altText: Linda Thomas-Greenfield sits at a desk, flanked by others, with a folder of documents, microphone and a 'United States' sign

props.synopsis: After days of delays, the UN Security Council adopts a watered-down resolution urging faster aid supplies for Gaza — but a call for an "urgent suspension of hostilities" is dropped to avoid another American veto.

title.children: UN Security Council passes Gaza aid resolution, avoiding veto as US and Russia abstain

image.altText: She sits in a camp chair wearing colourful red and orange clothes

props.synopsis: The Aboriginal Legal Service of Western Australia says its lawyers are paid up to $42,000 a year less than they would at Legal Aid WA, making attraction and retention difficult.

title.children: Calls for extra legal resources to avoid further 'catastrophic failures' in WA justice system

image.altText: Jakara Anthony holds an Australian flag

props.synopsis: Jakara Anthony claims her fifth World Cup freestyle skiing crown in 20 days in an incredible run of dominance from Australia's Olympic champion.

title.children: Five titles in 20 days: Jakara Anthony's golden December continues with another World Cup win

image.altText: Concept art showing an AFL oval and players with spectators watching from a nearby pavilion.

props.synopsis: The Rosny Parklands site, next to the Eastlands shopping centre, will host two MCG-sized ovals, an auditorium, indoor training area and swimming recovery facilities for a Tasmanian AFL team.

title.children: 'Highly visible central location': Rosny Parklands chosen as Tasmanian AFL team training site

image.altText: A black and white mounted stenograph of water flowing through a gully, land has been washed away

props.synopsis: The Glenorchy landslide of 1872 is still used to model future debris flow risks in parts of Tasmania with heavy rainfall deemed the biggest risk.

title.children: In 1872, houses shook and there was a 'deafening roar' as part of kunanyi/Mount Wellington slid away

image.altText: A young couple is handed a set of silver house keys.

props.synopsis: It's now common knowledge that loans and gifts from family are a large part of breaking into the housing market. But how is parental financial support being used in other areas?

title.children: The 'bank of mum and dad' might be crucial for buying a house, but new research shows it goes well beyond that

image.altText: A baby sleeps resting on someone's arm.

props.synopsis: A publicly-funded home-birthing scheme in Canberra has now successfully delivered more than 100 babies, and is set to expand.

title.children: There's more to baby Miles's birth story than being 'really big'

image.altText: A 'razor grinder' cicada on a rough bark tree trunk.

props.synopsis: The cicada's distinctive courtship call is the soundtrack to an Australian summer and in parts of the country it's the most penetrating it's been in years. Just look out for "cicada rain".

title.children: Cicadas are so loud their chorus is often above local noise restrictions and there are a lot around this year. Here's why

image.altText: A composite of a reconstruction of St Nicholas's face next to a photo of an elderly man dressed as Santa Claus.

props.synopsis: St Nicholas's generosity and gift-giving inspired the Christmas legend of Santa Claus. But instead of climbing down chimneys to deliver presents, the real-life bishop from ancient Greece would secretly leave bags of gold on windowsills and doorsteps.

title.children: Who was the real Santa Claus? We sort the facts from the fiction
